bug.short_desc: "Expires" HTTP header incorrectly set, prevents caching

long_desc.thetext:
The Expires HTTP header returned by just about every page on EPIC is set to some time in 1981. Despite the cache-control setting set to cache, these pages can't easily be cached either by the browser, proxies and caches because their content is considered expired.
5 Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT 6 Cache-Control: cache

I've made changes to the site so that it has a 1 hour expire time.
Date: Mon, 18 Dec 2006 15:52:26 GMT Server: Apache/2.2.0 (Fedora) X-Powered-By: PHP/5.1.4 Expires: Mon, 18 Dec 2006 16:04:23 GMT Cache-Control: cache Pragma: no-cache Age: 2883 Content-Length: 54300 Connection: close Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
200 OK
This can be seen on http://sandbox.eclipseplugincentral.net
This has been pushed live and AFAIK solved the problem
Looks good, thanks.

bug.short_desc: Bugzilla version defined via committertools doesnt show up

long_desc.thetext:
Hi,
I used committer tools / bugzilla self management in order to add Version="1.0.1" to Product DSDP / Target Management .
The new version shows up in the committertools bugzilla manager, but it does not show up when I create a new bug report in bugzilla, or try to modify an existing one.
Am I missing something?

Fixed. It seems that the previous version of bugzilla updated it's version cache file on different(more) page requests(now just on the edit version/milestone/product pages), so this went unnoticed. I've added a couple of lines to the bugzilla self management tools which force bugzilla to update it's cache files.
-M.

long_desc.thetext: I'm currently using the clean up wizard with different settings per project (one for legacy code, one for new code). I.e., when saving the current editor, the project specific "Clean Up On Safe" settings should be used and not the workspace settings.

create or replace PROCEDURE EQUIP_PATH_TO_ROOT (equip_tree_id IN INTEGER DEFAULT 0, path OUT VARCHAR) AS curr_node_id INTEGER; BEGIN curr_node_id := equip_tree_id; LOOP SELECT tree.parent_id, type.name || '/' || path INTO curr_node_id, path FROM EQUIPMENTS_TREE tree INNER JOIN EQUIPMENTS_TYPE type ON tree.equipments_type_id = type.id WHERE tree.id = curr_node_id; EXIT WHEN curr_node_id = 0 OR curr_node_id IS NULL; END LOOP; END;

bug.short_desc: Customer would like capability to have dynamic update to datapool when source csv file is changed

long_desc.thetext: We would like to have datapools update dynamically when "source" CSV file changes. Perhaps a datapool can be created as "virtual", that is, as a link to the actual CSV file.

As far as I know CSV files can only be imported to datapool elements. Import operations are one-shot operation.
What appends when the user edits the datapool object created from the csv ? Should we update the original csv to make them in sync ? Sounds weird.
Could you explain your vision in more details, please ?

I do not have much more details myself. From what I have gathered from the customer-submitted defect, there is a need to be able to update the contents of the datapool from a CSV file automatically, if the contents of the CSV file should change. In my opinion, what they *really* want is that Datapool be a facade to a data stored elsewhere, much like ODBC/JDBC. So that in playback time, the data pulled from the Datapool in fact comes from whatever real datasource is used by the datapool (CSV file, Database, Excel file etc). The actual data is not stored in the Datapool itself, as we do today. When such datapool is created, user has to specify the linkage to the real data source. When that "real" data changes, the user does nto have to do anything to get it to his tests.

Some additional comments on this request. This request came from a performance tester. In these scenarios, the amount of data in a datapool is significantly large. The data is not input from the user by imported from an external data source (database, programmatically generated, etc.)
In these cases, the import is the primary means of getting the data into the datapool. As testing proceeds, imports have to be repeated anytime a column(datapool variable) is aded, or additional rows need to be added (sometimes as user loads increase, the size of a datapool might need to increase). So the import is a onetime operation but obviously gets repeated multiple times during a testing cycle by the user. In this case, the updates to the CVS happens somewhat frequently and they'd like to have better support for getting those changes into the tool. Related to this request may be a desire to just use a CSV format for the datapool source vs importing all of it into a EMF datapool format. For example, the definition of a datapool could actually be a reference to a column in a CSV file. In this case the data is not imported but just a reference to the referenced CSV file. This has some scalability/performance reasons to consider too, as parsing of CSV and finding values out of the CSV could be optimized to not load all the values into memory as EMF constraints currently require. This CSV reference would also meet this customer's use case and satisfy his end goals as well. Hope that additional background helps somewhat.

Updating target to future as requested by the PMC.
Enhancements are targeted to future if not in plan for the current release.

bug.short_desc: JSP Highlighting is flaky

long_desc.thetext:
on M4 candidate, JSP highlighting seems to not work right. Some tokens, such as <% are never highlighted. Others, such as strings in the JSP section may not be highlighted when file first opened, but will be if you move the curosr to that line.
I'm marking as major, expecially since this appears to be a regression.

The <% %> not highlighting is indeed a regression. It looks like it was caused by fixing bug 147866. I had also found another regression (bug 168956) caused by fixing bug 147866. I'm going to just going to say bug 168956 is a duplicate of this bug since both were regressions caused by fixing bug 147866.
The strings, etc in JSP sections sometimes not being highlighted when the file is first opened is actually an existing bug and not a regression. It looks like it only happens on the first line in the first jsp scripting area and only if the first line is on the same line as the jsp scriptlet delimiter like: <% int i=0; %> If it was: <% int i=0; %> Then it seems to highlight correctly.

Created an attachment (id=56122) org.eclipse.wst.sse.ui.patch
Part of the fix for bug 147866 included adding the strikethrough & underline style preference. Actually, the UI was not added to the preference page. Only the code that handles the preferences. The problem was the fix needed some NPE guards. The fix is in ColorHelper#unpackPreferences Instead of immediately calling "st.nextToken().trim()" first check if "st.hasMoreTokens()" The NPE was being thrown during the loading of the highlighting colors and the NPE is thrown before the colors for <% %> are able to load, so that's why it's never highlighted.
As for the problem mentioned in bug 168956, the fix for bug 147866 also included changing the color picker button in the highlighting styles preference pages. The original button was just a button, and our code listens for when the button is clicked, a color selection dialog pops up, a color is selected, and that color preference is saved. The new button is a special color button that already knows that when a user clicks on it, it'll pop up a color selection dialog and return the color selected. The problem is the old button listener code is still being called with the new color button, so that's why the color selection dialog pops up twice. The fix is in StyledTextColorPicker#createControls.

Created an attachment (id=56123) org.eclipse.jst.jsp.ui.patch
Classes modified: LineStyleProviderForJava & LineStyleProviderForJSPEL
As previously mentioned bug 147866 added code to handle the strikethrough & underline style for highlighting. Changes were made to AbstractLineStyleProvider, but LineStyleProviderForJava & LineStyleProviderForJSPEL do not extend AbstractLineStyleProvider so it did not pick up the changes. So this patch adds the same changes made in AbstractLineStyleProvider to these 2 classes.
*** Bug 168956 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Thanks for the patches, Amy. I think this regression is important to fix in M4, so I've released the patches for builds > 12/28.
closing

bug.short_desc: [Vista] Windows Vista, execution history timestamp is in GMT

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: TPTP4.2.1.1_1127
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Execute a TPTP URL Test on Windows Vista 2. Notice that the execution histories in Test Navigator appear with a time expressed in GMT instead of local time.
I think this is bordering on major, because it is a very cumbersome and unpleasant experience for the user to pick the execution results they are interested in when they look at the local time and must figure out what time it is in GMT.
More information:
Reassign to Bianca.

The code is now using the ICU4J function to format the timestamp into a display string based on the default locale. This API returns the time based on current locale on WinXP or 2000 or Linux. Looks like the API doesn't quite work on Vista yet. Need to look for alternative to workaround this.

(In reply to comment #2)
Thanks Bianca. In the meantime, can you submit a ICU4J defect (http://bugs.icu-project.org/trac)?

During my vista testing, the test log viewer can display the time in the current system time zone.
DuWayne, could you try change the Time Zone on your system from "Date and Time" > Change date and time settings... > Change Time Zone, and see if the test log viewer changes the display of time with the current time zone (I restarted eclipse after changing the system time zone)?

So, on two Vista machines, I see the same thing, GMT time stamps even though local time is set to Eastern. Changing the time zone and then changing back to Eastern and re-starting the workbench had no effect.
I noticed the same problem on RPT test logs, so it is not just TPTP.
It sounded like you were able to make the problem go away somehow that I am unable to reproduce. By default, it seems the problem will be there for our users.
This is a JVM defect that has been fixed in the IBM JVM 1.5 SR4.
Deferring to 4.4 as agreed on Test project meeting on Jan. 15 2007.

Since this issue appears to be a JVM defect, this defect will cover both the GMT time stamp found in both the Test Navigator and Test Log View.
Bianca/Duwayne: Do you know if this problem has been found using the Sun JVM?

According to Earnest, the defect is also in the Sun JVM and notes indicated it is targeted to be fixed in Sun JVM 1.6.
I'm thinking this JVM time stamp issue be noted somewhere in the install notes or release notes for all versions of TPTP on Vista. The issue will be around for quite some time.

(In reply to comment #9)
Agreed. Can you open a Test.Doc defect for the 4.2.2 and 4.3.1 readmes?
Sizing updated as provided by Bianaca.
Targeting to future since cannot be contained in 4.4.
Targeting to future since cannot be contained in 4.4.

bug.short_desc: Cannot set connection info on SQL editor

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: I20061214-1445
Steps To Reproduce: [using DTP 1.0 RC2]
1. Create a connection profile to an Oracle database using a 10.x driver, make sure schema is visible in the Data Source Explorer (i.e. it connection profile works) 2. Edit some SQL file 3. Right click SQL file editor, chose "Set connection info" 4. Choose the previously created connection profile
Dialog says "There is no connection profile associated with this resource. Select a connection profile type/name", next button remains disabled. It ignores that a connection profile had been chosen.
More information: will attach screen shot of dialog
Created an attachment (id=55858) shows blocked dialog

Jorg,
I tried to repro using Oracle 10 XE and Windows XP. Could not get the problem described here -- this could be an OS difference (note Linux reported here). Assigning to SQL Dev for further investigation.
Move to DTP1.5 for further investigation

I tested this on Ubuntu and found that the problem is the dialog validator. If you ignore the "There is no connection profile associated..." message and just select the db type, connection profile and database (which you might have to type in yourself -- on some distro the combo is a bit flaky), and click "OK", the connection is established and you can execute queries as expected.
I'd like to suggest that we comment out the validation string for the moment, until we can investigate further. This is because, while the validation message is nice, it is not absolutely necessary for using the dialog, and gives the false impression that the connection can not be made.

Update for DTP 1.0:
Removed the confusing text from the dialog by changing
org.eclipse.datatools.sqltools.internal.sqlscrapbook.connection.ConnectionInfoDialog#createDialogArea(...)
Post DTP 1.0: Determine why this does not refresh on Linux.
Fixed in 180481.

Steps: 1) Create class extending Copier nested type 2) F3 on the superclass, opening EcoreUtil$Copier.class 3) CTRL+O.

Type some characters to match method names, then CTRL+O starts working normally.
Can reproduce using 3.3 M4.
Fixed in HEAD. Available in builds > N20061218-0010.

bug.short_desc: Generated Ant Script to export plugin projects not working

long_desc.thetext: Using export option in Manifest.mf file of eclipse I exported a plugin project and with the option "Save as Ant Script" checked. On running the saved ant script using the eclipse antrunner the jar file is not getting exported in the specified destination directory. But I'm getting a message of Build-Successfull.
I can look into this one

Figured it out. What is happening is the PDE task is scheduling an export job to run asynch. When run in the workbench, the ant task will return and the export job will begin.
When running it with the AntRunner application, the runtime exits after the ant task completes. The result is the export job not getting a chance to run.
The fix is to check to see if the task is being called by the AntRunner application, and if so, don't return until the export job has completed. Modified org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.ant.BaseExportTask.

bug.short_desc: Provide test suite/log version support.

long_desc.thetext:
Provide test suite/log version support.

The test log would contain version information about the test case/suite that created the log so these references would change over time as the test case/suite changes (additions/modifications/deletions).

(In reply to comment #1) > I wonder if other components also need updating? > e.g. should every plugin with extension points be altering their > build.properties to include schemas in the source distribution?
Wonder no more. Yes, all extension point schemas should be included in the source distribution. The source distros are intended for people who are developing using the API supplied by the binary bundle. The schemas are used by PDE to validate and define extensions.

bug.short_desc: Make ListChange Analyzer reusable

long_desc.thetext:
It would be nice if the algorithm to compute the delta between two ELists could be made reusable, i.e. use it to produce deltas that are not instances of the shipped change model. I have attached a proposal for two classes that make this possible and are compatible with the shipped change model.
Ed: This seems like a reasonable approach. This seems related a little bit to bug #127965.
Created an attachment (id=55862) AbstractEListCompare.java
Created an attachment (id=55863) ChangeEListCompare.java

The change is committed to CVS.
We didn't created the "very abstract" list you've suggested (the one that doesn't require the objects defined in the Change model). Let me know if this is an issue.

It was my idea to move the "very" abstract analyzer down to org.eclipse.emf.common.util (the plugin where EList resides) so that it is reusable with *any* EList without having to depend on the change model plugin. Do you think this is a big issue?

At this moment, at least to me, this would sound like a solution looking for a problem ;-)
But of course I may be completely wrong (wouldn't be the first time ;-))... Do you have a concrete scenario in which you would use something different than a ListChange to describe the difference bettween the lists?

Created an attachment (id=58127) Another possible approach.
Perhaps something like this would make sense. Since lists must have types in 5.0, the original patch doesn't really work so well. I'd really like to understand the use case before we make any further changes...

Eike,
1) Yes, I thought putting it in ECollections would be good. The logic is directly analogous to what setEList does (and once could trivially use it to implement setEList). 2) The override hooks also have a different signature, i.e., only the arguments needed to effect the change are passed, e.g., remove and move aren't passed the object. 3) Yes, this way it can be used for anything, not necessarily for creating some type of description. 4) Everything from now on will use generics since the whole EMF code base is now free of warnings about using raw types.
So you're happy with this and I should commit it? Could you show a little example of how you will use this? (Marcelo will be frustrated that we aren't reusing this logic in the Change model but rather have a copy of it, but it's not huge, and even setEList is analogous already.)

Created an attachment (id=58199) A version that templatizes the list's element type
This version of the approach will make it easier to call the method for a list with any type of item (just as for setEList). Certainly setEList could be implemented using this new class, but making the oldList not be an EList means that we can't use EList.move (without an instanceof test), and I doubt such a change would make it run faster. So I'm not totally thrilled with the old list not being an EList for this reason; you're sure your application example couldn't just cast to EList instead? :-) Using this for the change model itself is possible too, but we'd need to create a new instance (each time or cache one) that knows about the list changes to add to (just as in your use case) and again, move is a problem and the delegation to an additional class would not speed things up.

Ed, I suggest a different approach: Leave the analyzer implementation in ECollections with EList as parameter type which is logical since it is provided by *E*MF. I will copy it and change the type to List. This is not so nice from a maintenance perspective but it has an additional advantage for me: When I made the usage prototype I realized that also my server could use the analyzer to answer load requests for objects that are already loaded with former revisions. As I said the server is not required to have EMF installed, so even if your analyzer has List as a parameter type, it would simply not be there.
I hope you and Marcelo are not angry! For me it's and possibly others it's good to have the algorithm separated anyway.
Thank you ;-)
It may well be that in the future I decide to let the CDO server require org.eclipse.emf.common so that I can use EList and your analyzer version.

attachment.desc: A version that templatizes the list's element type

bug.short_desc: [Progress] busy spinners are too fast

long_desc.thetext:
Only having used them for a few days I'm torn on whether the busy spinners in views provide more benefit than distraction, since the Italics of view titles already conveyed this information, and their taking a way the icon makes it harder for me to find the view by icon/color. Perhaps this wouldn't be as much of a problem if they overlayed over the existing icon rather than replacing it entirely.
But there may be a UI design rationale here that I'm missing. However, if they remain could the animation be slowed down to the slow rate along the line of the internal browser's page loading animation? At the current fast rate the eye is constantly drawn to this distracting animation, whereas it seems like the only interesting events are when it has started, whether it is still going on when you check the view (often view element decorations show this), and when it stops.
See also https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=155083#c3
So Mik what is your request? That we make them an overlay or that we slow them down?

See Bug 168081 for the request for progress in the view (it is a similar problem so they should be discussed together).
Renaming to reflect the remaining issue
See also bug 167655.

I have now have used similar progress indicators in Vista and Office 2007 for long enough that I managed to formulate an opinion: * I think it would be best for the view icons not to disappear. The icons are key to quickly distinguishing which view is which, and if two views both have busy spinners, and they're stacked on next to each other (e.g., I keep Mylar's Task List on top of the Synchronize view) the result is disorienting because views can no longer be distinguished by icon. * The progress indication is valuable and should be easy to notice since it means the view contents could be changing, but the visual effect/animation should be subtle and slow as not to make the eye jump to it involuntarily (fast movement forces our saccades to focus on the motion involuntarily, although I think I've already trained myself to ignore the Synchronize view spinner).
I see the following options: 1) Overlay a progress bar animation on the bottom of the view icon. If this took something like 16x6 pixels at the bottom of the it could be visible enough without disrupting the icon too much. Or if something like a spinning or JUnit stacking style overlay can be squeezed into the bottom-right that could work too. Markus mentions this on bug 167655. But as bug 168081 points out this would need to look good both for busy state and for actual progress (+1 for making that API). 2) Make the progress indicated on the view tab itself. This can be done via a progress style gradient that sweeps across either the view tab, or the top few pixels of the view itself. Vista does something a bit like the former, and Outlook 2007 does the latter: below the Inbox view/panel, if you fill out a search progress will be indicated while the contents populate. The effect is subtle, clear, and noticeable. This kind of thing could be very helpful for search-based navigation in views. I'll attach a screenshot. 3) JUnit's progress indicator is hard to beat, for JUnit. I would personally prefer something that was standard across views. But another alternative is to ask the view to contribute the animation.
Added Kimberley to CC since this could be related to forms progress indication.

Created an attachment (id=56814) Outlook pane progress indicator
Note just below "All Mail Ite..."

(In reply to comment #5) Thanks Mik.
I agree they are too fast. The original animation is slower, if that can be preserved.
Having said that, I have to weigh in on the presence of these indicators: In short, I don't think they should be used at all in the tabs to replace or to overlay the view icons.
I'm not sure if comments are best made here or in bug 168081 but I'll make them here for convenience and in response to a couple points already made.
> * I think it would be best for the view icons not to disappear. (see full text above in comment #5) Yes, I agree. The view icons should remain visible. Unlike tabbed browsers' use of the loading animation, there's a lot more going on in an IDE where multiple views and editors are open -- not necessarilly stacked but occupying various locations in the UI. I see two issues: 1) as you've stated, you lose the at-a-glance recognition of the view/editor, and 2) if multiple animations are happening at once, the noise factor increases considerably.
> I see the following options: > 1) Overlay a progress bar animation on the bottom of the view icon. (see full text above in comment #5) I recommend against the overlay animation idea for the same reason as stated above: 2) if multiple animations are happening at once, the noise factor increases considerably. Because it's impossible to draw the line of what views/editors use such a mechanism, and random and widespread use could mean "blinkies" all over the place, it makes better sense to stick with the more subtle, and I believe effective, mechanism across the board: the italicized tab label.
> 2) Make the progress indicated on the view tab itself. (see full text above in comment #5) Something like the Outlook 2007 example works nicely when the view or editor is in focus, and the animation takes place below the tab level. The forms UI is aiming at something like this, except that it uses an animated GIF in place of the resource object, as shown in bug 17202. This simply shows busy though, not progress. For the latter, some textual indication within the view or editor content space should suffice. The missing piece here seems to be a place to show some visual, and textual, progress within views where there is currently no space reserved to do so. I like your thoughts Mik but personally don't have the bandwidth to explore ideas. Perhaps this is something Tod could have explored within the scope of the platform UI when cycles permit.

An important thing to note about the progress indication is that it is almost always showing indeterminate progress rather than some sort of progress that can show work done. Showing progress in the tabs would look like the progress indicator at right bottom of the IDE - always running and no indication of how much work is done.
In that respct it is more like a dirty state indication - i.e. don't bother with this view as the contents are being rebuilt.
The problem with the bold/italics idea is that it is a metaphor no one else uses (to my knowledge) whereas progress in tabs is a well known metaphor for "incomplete". Firefox is the best example of this.
With your outlook example do you think you wouldn't still have the issue of two many things running at once?

(In reply to comment #9) > An important thing to note about the progress indication is that it is almost > always showing indeterminate progress rather than some sort of progress that > can show work done.
Yes, understood. There are two different types: 1) showing activity (busy); 2) showing actual progress.
> The problem with the bold/italics idea is that it is a metaphor no one else > uses (to my knowledge) whereas progress in tabs is a well known metaphor for > "incomplete". Firefox is the best example of this.
Italics in tabs *is* an eclipse convention. I'm not sure we need validate that by finding similar usage in other products.
That said, this is being used in Firefox, though there is more going on in the Firefox case: icon animation + italics + red text while loading tabs in the background to show activity only. Italics + red text colour stays until explicitly viewed. To show actual progress, they are using purple colour (customizable) to show that (see attached images to come).
I can't help but say again, showing an animation for busy or progress, or both, in the tab will make the eclipse UI one busy and distracting place to do work. The subtler cue of italics to show some busyness seems to work nicely.
You might want to have a look at this FF Add on if you haven't seen it already: https://addons.mozilla.org/firefox/1122/
> With your outlook example do you think you wouldn't still have the issue of two > many things running at once? If I understand this correctly, it shows within the view space, below the level of the tab. In that way it is only seen when the view is in the foreground. Mik could probably shed more light on that.
Created an attachment (id=56910) Firefox tab loading behaviour

>Yes, understood. There are two different types: 1) showing activity (busy); 2) >showing actual progress.
Our tab support does not handle the second case. That would be done with a different affordance.
>That said, this is being used in Firefox, though there is more going on in the >Firefox case: icon animation + italics + red text while loading tabs in the >background to show activity only. Italics + red text colour stays until >explicitly viewed.
We had a look around yesterday and noticed that as well. I think we need some sort of textual affordance anyways as we don't show tabs images that are not at the top of the tab stack.
>showing an animation for busy or progress, or both, >in the tab will make the eclipse UI one busy and distracting place to do work. >The subtler cue of italics to show some busyness seems to work nicely.
I think we should try it with a subtler indicator first - the one you see is taken from forms and not used in as prominent a place. The consensus for most people we polled was that they liked the animation but that it did not need to be so busy. I'll investigate this with Kelvin.
>If I understand this correctly, it shows within the view space, below the level >of the tab. In that way it is only seen when the view is in the foreground. Mik >could probably shed more light on that.
This is the sort of thing worth looking into if we ever support determinate progress in views.
Removing the dependancy on Bug 168081 as determinate progress is a different feature request
Using I20070116-1510 I'm still not happy with the icon: - it sometimes flickers - it is not an exact circle (the borders aren't edgy) - it sometimes stops rotating for a very short time

I have the same issues with the current solution. Its a bit weird, because the animation looks pretty smooth when displayed in my image-app. Could it be the speed of the animation makes it look bad (noticed that the animation runs slower when displayed in my image-app)

(In reply to comment #14) > Using I20070116-1510 I'm still not happy with the icon: > - it sometimes flickers > - it is not an exact circle (the borders aren't edgy) > - it sometimes stops rotating for a very short time
The icon will is in the design cue to be improved and replaced. However, I'd like this particular animation to be used in the forms header, below the tab level, to show the editor is loading. It was not designed for the tab.
pardon the multiple typos in my last response.

(In reply to comment #10) > > With your outlook example do you think you wouldn't still have the issue of > two > > many things running at once? > If I understand this correctly, it shows within the view space, below the level > of the tab. In that way it is only seen when the view is in the foreground. Mik > could probably shed more light on that.
The thing with the Outlook approach is that you can make it as subtle as you like. If it is 2px tall, and a *very* slow animation, than it can avoid the bug of repeatedly drawing your eye to it. But the whole point of introducing this idea was to figure out some way of avoiding the replacement of the icon. But it's probably still too much for showing busy state, and Outlook uses it for letting the user know that it is finding matches.
> You might want to have a look at this FF Add on if you haven't seen it already: > https://addons.mozilla.org/firefox/1122/
Using Firefox as an example of what Eclipse should do is a bad idea: * Eclipse has a *much* more thorough, consistent, and extensible visual design than Firefox, especially where multiple views are concerned. * Firefox uses the tab icon to show a site's "favicon.ico". It doesn't know what icon should show until that has been retrieved from the server. * Even if that wasn't the case, the plug-in Kim refers to does a way better job showing progress, with it's Vista-style progress overlay on the tab itself.
> I can't help but say again, showing an animation for busy or progress, or both, > in the tab will make the eclipse UI one busy and distracting place to do work. > The subtler cue of italics to show some busyness seems to work nicely.
I couldn't agree more with Kim. While I proposed alternatives because I though that this has been decided as necessary, I think that even a very slow busy spinner icon replacement will be a significant *degradation* of the UI. There are at least three concrete problems with it: * The disorientation of icons disappearing. * The involuntary movement of the eye's saccades to the animation, which in some cases will run for over a minute (e.g. large Synchronize). * The ridiculous and distracting effect this will have when several visible views do this all at once.
So I'm wondering if someone could clearly state the problem this is addressing? I realize that techy and early adopter people like this stuff because it shows them more of what's going on (I liked it at first too). But are users really complaining that they're getting confused because they don't know when a view is busy, and when it's contents are changing? I always thought that the italics was very clear about this, especially since there is a nice visual consistency between currently-refreshing view elements going italic and the view title itself going italic. I could maybe see putting the little clock overlay onto the bottom-right of the view if it is necessary, since that tends to be used consistently too, but can't see why any more than that is needed to address this problem.
As a concrete example, imagine what this would look like with Mylar. In a default configuration the view goes busy every 20 minutes, and can stay busy for a minute or two if the network is slow. Business is very clearly indicated to the user with the affected elements' contents going italic and getting the little clock overlay. For 1.0 we opted against having the view title go italic because that seemed too distracting, but we were in the progress of changing that in order to follow that guideline. However, if this change happens there is simply no way we could warrant distracting users by hooking into the animation-based showBusy mechanism. I imagine that other integrators whose views synch repeatedly over the network would react similarly.

>Even if that wasn't the case, the plug-in Kim refers to does a way better job >showing progress, with it's Vista-style progress overlay on the tab itself.
I'll point out again that we are showing business not progress. It would be a constant 2 pixel animation on te bottom of a tab this way.
>So I'm wondering if someone could clearly state the problem this is addressing?
The problem is that the italics we insuffecient information. By having a tab animation you could easily glance at the tab to tell you to look elsewhere as the contents are not complete.
In views like Synchronize and Problems this has proved to be very useful as frequently all they have is ingtermediate state as thier updates do not occur all at once.
The Package Explorer is another good example - I used to periodically get confused as to whether or notI had loaded all of my plug-ins from CVS while the decorator was working - the busy spinner is giving me a better cue.
Out of curiousity Mike do you run with the other animations enabled?

> The problem is that the italics we insuffecient information.
I think the italic view title (as in 3.2) is enough to tell that the view is busy. The animation adds no more information, but it catches the visual focus, although I'm not interested in the busy state most of the time (especially when working in another part).
> [..] do you run with the other animations enabled?
I have them enabled, since they help me see e.g. where a part is going when its fast view state is toggled. AFAIK, the busy spinner is the first animation that is long-running. All the others just intensify a user-triggered action and only last for a few milliseconds.

I think this has been a good discussion. The case Mik mentions where a view is busy often and for long periods is worth thinking about since I could believe that the animation has potential to be distracting. However, the current animation, which was only intended as a placeholder is (we all agree) too loud, and perhaps prejudicing us that any animation will be a problem.
Thus I'd like to see the new graphics in place to form an opinion since subtlety of treatment can make a huge difference.
At present the conclusion seems to be: 1. Italics alone is too subtle 2. Spinning is too much
With some discussion around whether replacement of the view icon is a problem or not.
Any ideas for something in between 1 & 2?

1. Please point me to some data (users screaming/customers screaming/vendors screaming) that convinces us that italics are too subtle. I'm having a very hard time buying into this argument.
2. Please reassure me that this feature isn't driven by a "me too" mentality. Related to my first point, it's hard to see this proposal as something more than let's copy what firefox does.
3. Please remember the pain we went through with the Eclipse 3.0 new look and feel. If there is data that convinces us that italics are too subtle then remember there's going to be long-time Eclipse users who appreciate this subtlety and will need a preference that allows them to continue to wear their comfortable threadbare slippers.
Please remove the spinner functionality and close this bug as won't fix.
AnimatedTab removed for build >20070123

(In reply to comment #24) > AnimatedTab removed for build >20070123
That's great. Less is more :)
(In reply to comment #19) > Out of curiousity Mike do you run with the other animations enabled?
Yes, I always try to stick with the Eclipse defaults and keep animations enabled. In general I really like the strategy with animations in Eclipse, how they're subtle, not gratuitous, and tend to convey useful information. This can be so tricky with animations, because they're so loud. Take Vista, it's been my main OS for a month now, and it has a good number of gratuitous animations that don't convey anything but cuteness and the sophistication of Aero. Having dialogs flip into view isn't actually all that helpful and can get annoying. On the flipside you have MacOS, with fancy animations like windows slotting into the doc when you minimize them. But the Mac ones tend to convey useful information (e.g., user knows where to look for the icon when they need it again). So it's great to see the Eclipse UI both experimenting with more animations, and not using them gratuitously.
Related question: what about editors that need to load content, where such animations arguably have more of a home (e.g. compare editor, forms editors that refresh). Is there a bug where that UI being discussed (e.g. will the spinner slow down, whether the indication should be on the form as visible in one of the new mockups, or on the editor icon as it is currently). This UI is very relevant to Mylar because the contents of our editors are often stored remotely (e.g. on Bugzilla server).
Mik, Form editors already support 'busy' animation in the header area (to the left of the title) since 3.2.

(In reply to comment #26) > Mik, Form editors already support 'busy' animation in the header area (to the left of the title) since 3.2.
Right. But what I was pointing out is that now we have an SDK editor also shows its busy status by temporarily replacing the editor icon that shows in the editor tab with the busy animation (the CompareEditor does this while it is loading a diff from CVS). So I'm wondering what the recommended UI convention here is. E.g., if a forms-based editor that needs to do a background load or update of its contents, should it be putting the spinner in the editor tab *and* in the forms header? Seems OK to have one (slow) spinner going for the case where the user really has to wait on the editor input to load, but having two spinners would look weird.

That is correct. Form editor spinner predates the one in the tab area and two of them together are too much. I was merely trying to bring this functionality to your attention. It definitely does not help in the general case.

Of course you now have an inconsistency as forms based editors have this facility and now there is no such facility for editors in general.
Part of the reason this work was initially done was to bring the general UI look and feel and the forms looks and feel into each other (this is the reason the ide now uses forms).
With background editor save coming into 3.3 the inconsistency becomes even more apparent as we have no way except for a italics to indicate the editor is saving without actually opening it.

Forms are not bound to workbench parts i.e. one can place a anywhere. For this reason, it is good that there is a way to indicate activity in a form. This is similar to some web site pop-up windows that have an explicit 'close' link inside even though most WSs also provide that functionality in the window trim.
This issue is very easy to solve. For the time being, form-based editors that want to indicate long running saving operation (or any other open-ended operation), can use the animation. If/when the workbench comes up with a general-purpose solution for all parts, we can suggest form-based editor owners to switch to the general mechanism. Having both at the same time is of course not the way to go.
Verified in 20070206-0010

bug.short_desc: [WorkingSets] ModifyWorkingSetDelegate does too much work on selection change

long_desc.thetext: The full state of the operation is calculated whenever the selection changes. Instead, we should minimally determine action enablement (only IAdaptables and no IWorkingSets) and leave the rest for the fill() methods.

Fix in HEAD. The item is now enabled for any selection containing all IAdaptables and no IWorkingSets and it is only when the submenu is displayed that the heavy lifting is done. In the event that there are no working sets that can be modified then the disabled action "no applicable working sets" is shown.
Verified in source in I20070206-0010

bug.short_desc: move debug commands to core plug-in

long_desc.thetext:
In 3.3 M3, the org.eclipse.debug.ui.commands package was added to the debug-ui plug-in to provide retargettable debug commands. These commands should be moved to the core plug-in as they do not (need to) reference any UI interfaces. As well, since these command interfaces are replacements for the standard "command interfaces" (ITerminate, etc.), which live in the core, it makes sense for these commands to live in the core as well.
The original command API was based on the use of an IStatusMonitor to accept progress information and collect enabled state as a result. Other platform teams suggest to break the progress reporting and result collection into two arguments sent to a command to be more consistent with the "result collector" pattern used in the platform and to avoid overriding the function of a progress monitor.

Moved the commands to org.eclipse.debug.core.commands. Implementations of the commands for standard debug models have also been moved to the core plug-in. The status monitor has been split into a result collector (status/boolean collector, and progress monitor).
The progress monitor is now used to indicate an operation has been canceled.
Moved IStatusMonitor back to viewer's provisional package.

I like the separation of result collector and progress monitor, but it seems that it could create confusion as to which "done()" method should be invoked. Seems to me like there is no perfect solution to this problem so it's best to follow the most common pattern.

Pawel, I agree that having 'done' on the monitor and result collector is confusing. As well, having to cancel the monitor rather than the result is confusing. I wonder if it would be better to remove the progress monitor from the API, and just have a 'request' that embodies the result collector as well as "done" and "cancelation" support? After all, the command and content adapters are intended to process asynch requests. The debug platform could hook a progress monitor to the request implementation as needed (for example, as results are added to the request, we can update the progress - rather than having clients worry about it).

Yes - the desire to move IStatusMonitor to the runtime was what drove me to the changes :-) However, I think that we might have a slightly different pattern here - i.e. a "request" pattern rather than a "result collector" pattern - we have results, but it is part of a request that can be canceled. So, I think we can put "isCanceled()" and "cancel()" on the request itself, as well as "done()". The names would change again to reflect this - IStatusRequest, IBooleanRequest, etc. I think the API would be more clear - i.e. how to cancel a request and mark it as complete.
It also makes it simpler to cancel a request before it has been started. For example, a requset might be in a queue and get cancelled before it comes to the front of the queue. In this case, there is no progress monitor to use to cancel it yet, since progress reporting has not started yet.
Fully agree :-)

Created an attachment (id=55933) patch
Here's a patch that uses the "request" style API. It turns out to be very similar to the old "status monitor" except there is no progress reporting in the API.
I'm not sure if we need to delegate progress reporting to clients (adapter implementations), or if we can just handle the progress in the debug platform and report progress as each request is processed. Currently, I don't know of any long running requests that need to report their own progress.
Thanks. I don't have a use case for a progress monitor in view or command adapters, so it's fine with me if it's left out.

Created an attachment (id=55995) patch
Update to previous patch... but wait there's more to come

Created an attachment (id=55996) patch
This is a second implementation of the "request" model. This patch uses a "request processor" to process "requests". Each request describes itself (i.e. step over, terminate, etc). A "command processor" is used to process all types of requests - so in this case we have a "debug command processor" to process commands for a debug model. Rather than registering a "step command" adapter, etc., just a "debug command processor" is registered.
I think this approach allows the request object to carry the data for the request, the results, and be cancelled. It also makes for a thinner API, but perhaps a less OO implementation as the request processor tends to have large switch statements to process requests.
The API may be simpler to extend - rather than defining new interfaces, just new command type constants need to be introduced. However, we have to consider how to add a command to an existing model when the command processor is already written - we may need to use an extension point to register request processors rather than adapters (to allow for more than one), with enablement expressins - so we know which model they apply to.
The same pattern could be applied to the viewer content/label adapters - i.e. convert them to "request processors".

Created an attachment (id=56002) updated patch
Updates when merging with HEAD.

Created an attachment (id=56289) update
I agree that the "IRequestListener" is an implementation detail. This patch moves that function to the "command request" implementation.
The justification for a "begin()" method on the request is to allow cleints to know when a request has actually started, as a processor may have a queue of requests and not start processing a request right away. However, I'm not sure how important this is (except for reporting progress).

Created an attachment (id=56304) patch update
Just attaching the latest version of this from my workspace.

Created an attachment (id=56363) patch
Looking at the alternatives I believe the "commands as separate interfaces" is a slightly better implementation as it allows for more extensibility and reuse. For example, if a debugger implementation is of the 'standard model' but adds some functions, the base 'command handlers' can be re-used and a the model can add its own command handlers for its special functions.
Since there can only be one adapter of a particular kind for any given object, it's harder to extend the "command processor" approach. That is, if a command handler has to handle all commands for a given model, then it's hard to extend.
This patch modifies the existing command interfaces, naming them as 'handlers' (which is what they really are), and gets rid of the progress monitor. A request is passed into the handler that can be canceled and contains the result.
Released cleaned up version of the patch to HEAD. The 'request' objects sent to the 'command handlers' also contain the objects to operate on now (similar to viewer update requests).
Please verify, Mike.

Thanks Darin, Just out of curiosity, what do you think of the idea of an IRequestMonitor as I described in comment #12? I thought it might be a clever way of combining the IRequest and IProgressMonitor without hurting anyone in the process ;-)
verified

bug.short_desc: jira query not synchronizing

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060921-0945
Steps To Reproduce: 1. create a jira repository 2. ensure it works with validate 3. add a query to the task list 4. try to synchronize the query
More information: step 4 fails and the tooltip on the query show 'Last Error: could not log in to server ...'
Step 2 however works fine with valid credentials and fails with invalid password - which I checked just to make sure it does anything at all...
This seems to be the same as bug 149503, but I did not have enough privileges to reopen that one

oh, forgot to mention that I also added
#proxy setup -Dhttp.proxyHost=10.192.147.7 -Dhttp.proxyPort=9119 -Dhttp.nonProxyHosts=20.20.*
eclipse's config.ini, but that makes no difference at all. This proxy also requires authentication, but since the jira server is in the 20.20.* domain I was hoping I did not have to add proxyUser and proxyPassword to this file....

I'll have to check how validate call is different from synchronization, but I can tell you right now, that "http.nonProxyHosts" currently does not support any wildcards. It is checked using
nonProxiedHosts.indexOf(hostname) == -1
So, you should have exactly the same name or ip address as used in server url for this jira instance. Let us know if it resolve your issue.
PS: Also note that -D options in eclipse.ini should be added after -vmargs. You can verify if it worked by looking in Help -> About Eclipse SDK -> Configuration Details. Here is how my eclipse.ini looks like:
-vm C:\jdk1.5.0_08\bin\java.exe -vmargs -Xverify:none -Xms90m -Xmx400m -XX:MaxPermSize=90m -XX:MaxNewSize=40m
that fixed the issue. had to use the full ip instead of a wildcard. Thanks! You may want to consider changing that though, since the Vm spec for that property states you can use wildcards

Eugene: we should update the FAQ. Should we be recommending that people put this into config.ini (as we do currently) or into eclipse.ini?
http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Mylar_FAQ#JIRA_Connector_troubleshooting
Diagnosed and resolved by Eugene.
I updated the FAQ. Not sure where config.ini came from. So, I just changed it to eclipse.ini

So you are not going to support the Java VM specification for the values of the http.nonProxyHosts property? From the documentaion for JDK1.5.0:
http.nonProxyHosts indicates the hosts which should be connected too directly and not through the proxy server. The value can be a list of hosts, each seperated by a |, and in addition a wildcard character (*) can be used for matching. For example: -Dhttp.nonProxyHosts="*.foo.com|localhost".
Shouldn't your code observe this documented behavior?
(In reply to comment #7) These properties are actually temporary work around. This stuff will be moved into the UI after JIRA core services will pass Eclipse legal process.

Hmm, so we're going to add another UI to set proxy information, in addition to (the ones I know about at the moment):
1. The one in Install/Update 2. The one in CVS 3. The one in Internet (WTP?)
It seems to me that this proxy management UI needs to go in the core eclipse platform, so it exists in only one place..... I know, not your problem, but before adding yet another UI for proxy settings, I would consider this issue.

(In reply to comment #9) There will be common proxy settings for platform. See bug 154100.
However we still need to allow to specify proxy per repository. See configuration for Bugzilla, Trac and Web repository connector. The only one that does not support that is JIRA.

bug.short_desc: Hardware requirements hard (impossible?) to find

long_desc.thetext:
Acerion wrote:
I am planning installation of eclipse software on my computer, but before doing that I would like to know HW requirements. So I did quick google search, and one of responses was - "go to eclipse.org and search for this information". So I did - I went to eclips.org. I bowsed a little here nad there - nothing. I typed 'hardware requirements' in search box - no direct information in top 10 results. Eclipse Newcomers FAQ? Nothing. Download - release notes? Just processor _family_. Eclipse FAQ? Nothing. Please, please - do something about it.
I searched for this information and couldn't find it either.

Eclipse has no specific hardware requirements. The Eclipse runtime runs on a vast array of hardware from embedded devices, to web servers and mainframes. It would be impossible to even attempt enumerating the possible hardware environments.
Instead, Eclipse has specific software requirements - namely an operating system and a Java runtime environment. These requirements are listed in the readme included with every build of the Eclipse platform (eclipse/readme/readme_eclipse.html), and on the download page of every release. For example, here is the readme for the 3.2.1 release:
http://www.eclipse.org/eclipse/development/readme_eclipse_3.2.1.html
See section 1 - Target Operating Environments

I got another one of these in the webmaster box:
I was not able to find the min./suggested system requirements for Eclipse. I did a search, but no luck. Would you add "System Requirements" for the various OS's somewhere? I see that others have posted similar questions on newsgroups, but there is a wide range of answers.
I don't believe it's an impossible question to answer as I believe that most people who ask the question are people who want to use Eclipse as an IDE - C++ IDE, PHP IDE, Java IDE, etc. If we can at least provide an answer to that specific audience, then I believe the world will be a better place.
This should definitely be an FAQ item on the Wiki, so I'll reopen and reassign to the Wiki. It could be part of the Official Eclipse FAQ:
http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/The_Official_Eclipse_FAQs
Maybe this bug should be reassigned to the Eclipse Packaging Project (EPP) when/if it gets created. It seems reasonable to attach system requirements to exemplary packages created.
Reassigning to EPP for consideration, as suggested in comment 3.

(In reply to comment #3) > Maybe this bug should be reassigned to the Eclipse Packaging Project (EPP) > when/if it gets created. It seems reasonable to attach system requirements to > exemplary packages created. >
Wayne, any thoughts on this? Eric, do you want to try drafting something up on the wiki? I'm thinking if we state hardware (and *software*) requirements we could avoid confusion like that of bug 191254. We can then link to these documents from the various download pages.

bug.short_desc: NPE when using mouse to select next editor

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: I20061214-1445
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Trigger next editor popoup (mapped to ctrl-tab for me) 2. Release Tab 3. Click one of the open editors in the popup (I only had two open) 4. NPE reported
More information: java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.kEventControlTrack(Widget.java:1068) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Control.kEventControlTrack(Control.java:1773) at
